title: 106_hr4594
content: The Act may be cited as the "Pediatric Diabetes Research and Prevention Act" and includes programs regarding diabetes in children and youth. The "Pediatric Diabetes Research and Prevention Act" establishes a National Registry on Juvenile Diabetes to collect data on incidence and prevalence. Long-term epidemiology studies on juvenile diabetes are conducted to follow individuals with type 1 diabetes for 10 years or more, providing valuable information on disease manifestations. The National Registry on Juvenile Diabetes collects data on disease manifestations, environmental triggers, complications, and potential study populations for clinical trials and genetic studies related to type 1 diabetes. The Secretary also addresses type 2 diabetes in youth. The Secretary will implement a national effort to address type 2 diabetes in youth by enhancing surveillance systems, expanding research, and assisting states in establishing health programs. Additionally, the Secretary will support regional clinical centers for innovative treatments for juvenile diabetes. The National Institutes of Health will support regional clinical centers for juvenile diabetes, providing well-characterized populations for study, trained clinical scientists, appropriate clinical settings, and statistical monitoring. The Secretary will lead a national effort to develop a vaccine for type 1 diabetes, focusing on research, development, and large clinical trials in children. The Loan Repayment Program under Part G of title IV of the Public Health Service Act is amended to include a new section after section 487E. The Loan Repayment Program is amended to include a new section for research on diabetes in children. The Secretary, in consultation with the Director of the National Institute of Diabetes and Digestive and Kidney Diseases, will establish a program to contract qualified health professionals for conducting diabetes research in children. The professionals will receive up to $35,000 annually to repay educational loans. Adjustments for cost of living may be made, and certain provisions will apply. The program established by the Secretary will provide up to $35,000 annually to qualified health professionals for conducting diabetes research in children. The program includes Type 1 and Type 2 diabetes in children, and appropriations are authorized for fiscal years 2001 through 2005. Authorization of Appropriations.--Sums are authorized to be appropriated for fiscal years 2001 through 2004 to carry out the program providing up to $35,000 annually for diabetes research in children.
